user_query: What's the difference between stocks and shares?
text-davinci-003_response: Stocks and shares are both used as investment vehicles, but there are some key differences between them. Generally, stocks refer to the ownership of a fraction of a company, while shares refer to the number of individual investments held by investors. Stocks represent an investment in a company’s future, while shares are a way of measuring equity holdings by individual investors. Stocks typically provide voting rights to their owners, allowing them to influence company decisions, while shares do not. Additionally, stocks tend to produce greater overall return potential over the long term whereas shares are typically viewed as a short-term or intermediate investment.

user_query: In what ways is IEX different than a typical dark pool or a typical exchange?

user_query: Does FIFO cost basis applies across multiple accounts?

This method is used to calculate the cost basis when selling multiple units purchased over time. When applying FIFO cost basis across multiple accounts, the accounting method considers the units that you've purchased in the first account, followed by the next account, and so on.

user_query: TFSA over-contributions: How would the penalty apply in this scenario?

user_query: How does the process of “assignment” work for in-the-money Options?
text-davinci-003_response:
In the money Options are contracts which give the optionholder the right to buy or sell the underlying asset, like a stock or bond, at the set strike price. When the option is in the money, meaning the strike price is below the current market value of the underlying asset, the optionholder has the right to exercise the option and buy or sell the underlying asset at the strike price. 
The process of assignment works when the option holder exercises the option. The option writer, also known as the counterparty, has the obligation to fulfill the option contract. If the option holder exercises the option and the counterparty is short the position, then the counterparty will be assigned. This means that the counterparty will receive an order to either buy or sell the underlying asset in order to fulfill the option contract. The counterparty must buy the asset if they are short a call option, and must sell the asset if they are short a put option. This process of assignment is also known as an "exercise by assignment". 
The option holder must then pay the counterparty for the underlying asset when the option is exercised. If the option holder is long the option, they will receive the proceeds from the sale of the underlying asset. On the other hand, if the option holder is short the option, they will owe the counterparty for the underlying asset. 
The process of assignment for in-the-money options ensures that the option contract is fulfilled and that no party can back out of the agreement. It is important to understand the process of assignment when trading in-the-money options since it can have a direct impact on the profitability of the trade.

user_query: How to reconcile final payment on installment sale for IRS form 6252?
text-davinci-003_response:
1. Calculate the amount of gain on the installment sale. Subtract the installment note's original base amount from the total of payments and cash received during the year.
2. Calculate the gain allocated to the year of the final payment. Multiply the gain on the installment sale calculated in step one by the percent of payments paid in the year of the final payment.
3. Prepare IRS Form 6252. Enter the gain allocated to the year of the final payment as ordinary income. List this amount in line 4 of IRS Form 6252 and also enter the total of payments and cash received in line 6 of the form.
4. Deduct any section 1245 gain recapture taxable amount related to the installment sale in the year of the final payment. The amount of gain recapture is calculated by subtracting the original basis of the installment note from the total of payments and cash received during the year.
5. Enter the section 1245 gain recapture taxable amount in line 8 of IRS Form 6252 and also add the gain recapture into the total ordinary income reported in line 9.
6. Calculate the taxes due for the final payment year. Subtract the gain allocated in step two from the total ordinary income reported in line 9 of Form 6252. Multiply the result by the applicable tax rate to calculates the taxes due in the final payment year.

user_query: What is the difference between FINRA share volume and NASDAQ share volume?
text-davinci-003_response:

NASDAQ share volume is a measure of how many shares of a given security have been traded on the NASDAQ exchange. It is different from FINRA share volume because it reflects only activity that has occurred on the NASDAQ exchange, and therefore does not include over-the-counter trades.

user_query: Option Theta: What conditions are needed for Theta > P/N, where P = option price, and N = days to expiration?
text-davinci-003_response: Theta is a measure of an option's time decay or rate of depreciation. For Theta to be greater than P/N, the option price would have to be decreasing faster than the rate of the inverse of the time to expiration (P/N). The faster the option price decreases relative to the rate of the inverse of the time to expiration, the higher Theta will be. Factors that could cause the option price to decrease faster than the inverse of the time to expiration include a drop in the underlying stock price, higher implied volatility, and higher demand for the option.

user_query: Why is RSU tax basis based on remaining shares after shares are witheld?

This way, the total value of the remaining shares is the amount that the taxpayer has realized in value from the RSU.

user_query: Covered calls: How to handle this trade?
text-davinci-003_response:
A covered call is a strategy that lets investors obtain additional income from an underlying stock they own through the sale of call options. The trader buys the underlying stock and in turn sells call options equal to the number of shares he/she owns. This results in a neutral to slightly bullish stance to the stock as the trader profits from the premium received from selling the call options.
When initiating a covered call, the investor should seek a strike price that is just above the current market value of the underlying stock. This will create a higher probability of the stock being called away at the strike price before the expiration date. If the stock reaches the strike price, the investor will have to sell the shares at the strike price.
The investor can manage the covered call trade by doing the following:
1. Establish a target profit or the size of the premium received.
2. Monitor the price of the underlying stock closely as it approaches the strike price.
3. If the call gets close to the strike, consider rolling the call up to a higher strike for additional income, or closing the trade before it gets called away.
4. If the stock price drops extremely below the strike, consider closing the trade early to avoid a large potential loss.

A reverse split, on the other hand, is when a company reduces the number of shares outstanding by effectively splitting multiple shares into one.

user_query: Changes in Capital Gains Tax in the US - Going to 20% in 2011?
text-davinci-003_response:
The Capital Gains Tax rate in the US did not change to 20% in 2011. The maximum federal rate is currently 23.8%. This rate encompasses both a 20% maximum tax rate on net capital gains as well as a 3.8% tax on certain net investment income that applies to taxpayers with adjusted gross incomes above $200,000 ($250,000 for married couples).
The Obama administration proposed in 2010 that the maximum federal rate on capital gains be 20%, while maintaining the 15% rate on those with incomes below $200,000 and couples below $250,000. The proposal was part of a broader tax policy effort that Congress rejected, so the 2011 capital gains tax rate remained unchanged.

user_query: Looking into investment bonds for the first time- what do I need to be aware of?
text-davinci-003_response:

Types of Bonds: A bond is an agreement between an issuer and an investor, where the issuer agrees to pay the bondholder a set amount of interest (usually paid semi-annually or annually) for a certain period of time. Common types of bonds include government bonds, corporate bonds, municipal bonds, and treasury bonds. 
2. Risk: Investing in bonds is generally considered a lower-risk investment than investing in stocks. However, bonds come with their own set of risks, such as interest rate risk, inflation risk, credit risk, and liquidity risk.

4. Duration: Duration is used to measure how long it will take for the bond to be paid back to the investor. A bond's duration can vary from just a few months to 30 or more years. 
5. Market Factors: Bond prices are affected by a variety of factors, such as changes in interest rates, macroeconomic conditions, and the performance of the issuer. It is important to understand how these factors can influence the yield and potential gains or losses on a bond investment. 
6. Tax Implications: Interest earned from bonds is typically subject to taxes, either at the federal or state level. It is important to factor in the impact of taxes when investing in bonds.

user_query: If I make over 120k a year, what are my options for retirement plans?

user_query: How do you calculate the rate of return (ROR) when buying and selling put options?
text-davinci-003_response:
To calculate the rate of return (ROR) when buying and selling put options, you need to first calculate the net profit or loss and then divide it by the total cost of the option. The formula is as follows:
ROR = (Net Profit or Loss / Total Cost) x 100
Net Profit or Loss = (Sale Price of Option – Purchase Price of Option)
Total Cost = (Premium for Put Option + Commissions)
For example, if you bought a put option with a premium of $5, and subsequently sold the same option for $7, and paid a $2 commission upon each transaction, your rate of return would be calculated as follows:
ROR = ((7 – 5) – (2 x 2)) / (5 + 2 x 2) x 100
= 3 / 9 x 100
= 33.33%

user_query: How are various types of income taxed differently in the USA?
text-davinci-003_response:
Earned Income (Wages, Salary, Tips, Bonuses): Earned income is subject to federal income tax and self-employment tax if applicable. Depending on the state, wages may also be subject to local or state income tax.
Unearned Income (Interest, Dividends, Capital Gains): Unearned income, such as investment earnings, is taxable at the federal level, but state taxation may differ. Interest income is taxed as ordinary income. Dividends and capital gain distributions are generally taxed at a lower, preferential rate. States may also have special tax rules for unearned income, such as a tax exemption for capital gains or special tax rates for dividends.
Rental Income: Rental income is taxable at the federal and state level. The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) treats rental income as ordinary income, which means it is generally taxed at your marginal tax rate. Some states may also impose additional taxes on rental income.
Self-Employment Income: Self-employment income is subject to federal income tax and self-employment tax. Depending on the state, self-employment income may also be subject to local or state income tax.
Social Security Income: Social Security benefits are generally taxable at the federal level, and in some cases, state level. Depending on your total income, up to 85% of your Social Security benefit may be taxed at the federal level.

user_query: GNUCash: How to count up equity?

2. Calculate the book value of equity. This will tell you the actual, tangible value that accounts for real income and other resources. To do this, subtract the liabilities from the total asset values and then divide by the total number of common shares outstanding.

user_query: How do government bond yields work?

It's better to optimize your taxes with deductions and credits after you've already negotiated a fair pay rate.

user_query: Does the Black-Scholes Model apply to American Style options?
text-davinci-003_response: No, the Black-Scholes Model does not apply to American Style options. American Style options can be exercised at any point during the option's life, and the Black-Scholes Model assumes that the option will only be exercised at expiration.

user_query: How do insurance funds work?
text-davinci-003_response: Insurance funds are managed by insurance companies. The purpose of the funds is to provide protection against a potential financial loss in exchange for a periodic premium payment to the insurance company. The insurance company will then invest the premiums collected from policyholders in a variety of securities, such as stocks, bonds, and other investments, to generate returns. The returns from the investments in the fund will then be used to pay the insured's claims and expenses in the event of a loss.

user_query: Should you diversify your bond investments across many foreign countries?
text-davinci-003_response: Yes, diversifying your bond investments across many foreign countries can help you to minimize risk and protect your investments against economic and political changes. It also allows you to potentially capitalize on any advantages and trends in different countries, as well as currency fluctuations. Additionally, global bonds can provide higher returns than domestic ones. Therefore, it is generally recommended that investors diversify their bond investments across many countries.

user_query: How much of each stock do index funds hold?
text-davinci-003_response: The exact proportion of each stock in an index fund varies depending on the specific index that the fund tracks, as well as other factors like the size of the fund. Generally, stocks in an index fund are weighted in proportion to their overall market capitalization, meaning the largest stocks in the index will have a larger proportion of the fund's holdings than the smaller stocks.

user_query: How late is Roth (rather than pretax) still likely to help?
text-davinci-003_response: Roth contributions are still likely to be helpful as long as you have earned income to contribute with. There is no definitive "age limit" that sets an end to Roth contributions. However, once you reach age 70, you can no longer make Roth contributions, as you must begin taking required minimum distributions from traditional IRA accounts. That said, you can still make Roth conversions up until the April 15 tax filing deadline in the year you turn 70.5, regardless of your age.

user_query: I am a Canadian resident who wants to gift my Adult US child CAD$175K. What are the tax implications?
text-davinci-003_response:
The tax implications for gifting this amount depend on the laws in both Canada and the United States. 
In Canada, anyone who gifts more than CAD$15,000 in a single year to a non-spouse recipient is subject to a tax called the "deemed disposition" which is based on the fair market value of the gift. This means that the donor may be required to pay capital gains tax on the difference between the gifted amount and the donor's cost basis of the property or gift.
In the United States, if the amount exceeds the annual exclusion of CAD$15,000, the recipient would be required to pay gifts and estate taxes. The recipient's state of residence may also have its own set of gift and estate tax laws.
It is best to consult with a financial advisor and/or tax professional in both Canada and the United States to fully understand the potential tax implications. Additionally, in some cases it may be more beneficial to set up a trust to avoid or minimize the tax implications.

user_query: Can I buy and sell a house quickly to access the money in a LISA?
text-davinci-003_response: No, you cannot quickly buy and sell a house to access money in a LISA. A Lifetime ISA must be held for at least 12 months before funds are eligible to be withdrawn without penalty. Funds taken out of a LISA before the 12 month period incur a 25% government charge.

user_query: ETFs are a type of mutual fund, correct?
text-davinci-003_response: No, ETFs are not a type of mutual fund. ETFs, or exchange-traded funds, are investment funds traded on stock exchanges, much like stocks. Mutual funds are investment funds that are not traded on an exchange.

user_query: How do you translate a per year salary into a part-time per hour job?
text-davinci-003_response: To translate a salary into an hourly rate for a part-time job, you must first calculate the yearly salary into a weekly salary. Then divide the weekly salary by the number of hours you plan to work. For example, if your salary is $50,000 per year and you plan to work 20 hours per week, your hourly wage would be $50,000/52 weeks = $962.50/week, $962.50/20 hours = $48.12/hour.

user_query: What's the best way to account for a risky investment - As an asset or an expense?
text-davinci-003_response: The best way to account for a risky investment is to treat it as a non-current asset. This is because you are investing in an asset and the return should be recognized in the future when the investment is realized. By accounting for it as an asset, you are able to track the value of the investment over time and recognize any gains or losses when the investment matures.

user_query: How do I read technicals for tickers that move together but are slightly different?
text-davinci-003_response: When reading technicals for tickers that move together, but are slightly different, it is important to review the historical price trends of each ticker. By looking at a chart of the two tickers, you can observe points of divergence or convergence, as well as any patterns that may emerge. It can also be helpful to review news events related to each ticker in order to gain an understanding of why they are reacting differently to the same drivers. Additionally, many charting software programs offer tools to compare the price action of two tickers which can be helpful in gauging the relative strength or weakness of each.

user_query: Are U.S. salaries typically measured/reported before tax, or after tax?
text-davinci-003_response: U.S. salaries are typically reported before taxes.

user_query: What is a “closed-end fund”? How is a closed-end fund different from a typical mutual fund?
text-davinci-003_response: A closed-end fund is an investment fund that has a fixed number of shares that are issued and traded on a public exchange. Unlike a typical mutual fund, the fund does not continuously issue and redeem shares to meet the demands of investors, but instead trades at the current market price when bought and sold. The fund is closed-ended in the sense that it does not add new shares as demand increases, so the price of the shares can be significantly higher or lower than its net asset value per share.

However, spending all money on a home can be a good investment, as it can appreciate in value, provide shelter, and build a sense of community. It really depends on individual circumstances and goals in order to make the best decision.

user_query: How useful is the PEG Ratio for large cap stocks?
text-davinci-003_response: The PEG Ratio can be a useful tool for analyzing the value of large cap stocks. PEG ratios measure the ratio of a stock's price-to-earnings ratio relative to its expected earnings growth. By comparing this ratio to those of other stocks, investors can gain an understanding of the overall value of a large cap stock relative to the rest of the market. However, it is important to understand that PEG ratios aren't necessarily a perfect tool for assessing the value of a stock, so other fundamental metrics should be used when making investment decisions.

user_query: What are futures and how are they different from options?
text-davinci-003_response: Futures are financial contracts that obligate the buyer to purchase an asset or the seller to sell an asset, at a predetermined future date and price. Futures are different from options in a few ways. Futures involve a legal obligation to buy or sell the underlying asset on the settlement date, unlike options which are contracts that give buyers the right to buy or sell at a certain price. Additionally, futures are marked to market daily, meaning that gains and losses are settled each day, while options are marked to market when expiring or when exercised. Finally, futures trading is less flexible than options trading, as there is often less time to react to price changes in the underlying asset.

user_query: Is it better to buy put options or buy an inverse leveraged ETF?
text-davinci-003_response: It depends on your risk tolerance and investment goals. Put options provide a lower risk way to potentially benefit from a decline in a stock or index, whereas inverse leveraged ETFs use financial derivatives to offer leveraged exposure to the inverse of an underlying index. The difference between the two is that with puts, you face a predetermined loss, whereas with inverse leveraged ETFs, your returns will depend on how successful the investment is in capturing the inverse moves in the index.

user_query: Over how much time should I dollar-cost-average my bonus from cash into mutual funds?
text-davinci-003_response: It is up to you to decide how long you want to dollar-cost-average your bonus into mutual funds. Of course, it is important to consider the tax implications involved with investing your bonus. Generally, it is recommended to invest your bonus over the course of several months or years—the longer you invest, the more time the money will have to grow and be affected by compound interest.

user_query: Is there any data that shows how diversifying results in better returns than just sticking to an all-stock portfolio?
text-davinci-003_response: Yes, there have been numerous studies showing that portfolio diversification improves returns and reduces risk. A famous paper written by Gary Brinson, Brian Singer and Gilbert Beebower in 1991 analyzed over 91 pension plans and concluded that all of the differences in return can be attributed to the asset allocation policy (i.e. how the portfolio is diversified). Another paper, written by Pierre Collin-Dufresne and Robert S. Goldstein in 2001, showed that diversifying into bonds improved returns and reduced the volatility of the portfolio. Finally, a more recent study by Hendrik Bessembinder and Talbot Bielefield in 2011 showed that diversifying into different asset classes, such as stocks, bonds and commodities, increased portfolio returns significantly over the buy-and-hold strategy.

user_query: Why would a company issue a scrip dividend and how will this issue affect me?
text-davinci-003_response:
A scrip dividend is an issuance of company shares or debentures in lieu of cash dividends. The company issues a “scrip” certificate redeemable at a later date for a fixed amount of the company’s stock.
The company may issue a scrip dividend for a variety of reasons, such as reducing debt, conserving cash flow, bolstering the price of its stock, or raising additional capital. It could be an attractive option for a company in times of financial difficulty.
If you are the owner of the company’s stock, then being issued a scrip dividend can be a good thing. The scrip dividend will help you increase your ownership position in the company, which, if all goes well for the company, should result in increased value for your shares.

user_query: I spend too much money. How can I get on the path to a frugal lifestyle?
text-davinci-003_response:
1. Create a budget and track your spending so that you know where and how you’re spending money.
2. Set financial goals and create a plan to reach them.
3. Cut out unnecessary spending like dining out, entertainment, and shopping.
4. Pay with cash or a debit card to avoid going into debt.
5. Consider a side hustle to generate some extra income to put toward debt and to build an emergency fund.
6. Find ways to save money on everyday items like groceries and household items.
7. Prioritize saving by setting up automatic transfers to separate savings accounts.
8. Shop around for the best deals and compare offers online.
9. Look for cheaper alternatives and DIY projects to save money.

user_query: Is it smarter to buy a small amount of an ETF every 2 or 3 months, instead of monthly?
text-davinci-003_response: It depends on your financial goals and overall retirement plan. Buying smaller amounts of an ETF more frequently could be beneficial if you don't have a lot of money to invest upfront or if you are trying to reduce risk/volatility by dollar-cost averaging.  However, it is important to keep in mind that by trading more frequently you could be subject to higher transaction costs and fees. Therefore, it might make sense to analyze the fees associated with a particular ETF before deciding how often you want to buy it.

user_query: Did I get screwed in taxes on a mutual fund dividend payment?
text-davinci-003_response: It depends on the specific situation. Generally, you are not 'screwed' in taxes on a mutual fund dividend payment as long as you understand the tax implications of the dividend. How you are taxed on the dividend payment depends on the type of mutual fund, whether or not it is a qualified dividend, if you are in a profit-sharing plan, or if the dividend is subject to capital gains taxes. Your tax advisor can answer any specific questions about taxation of the dividend payment.

user_query: How does it work when the same ETF is listed on several stock exchanges?
text-davinci-003_response: When an ETF is listed on multiple stock exchanges, it is essentially the same security and shares of this ETF are fungible across all listed exchanges. This means that investors can buy and sell the same ETF shares on different exchanges with the same underlying value and trading price. The benefit of having the same ETF listed on multiple stock exchanges is that it increases liquidity and competition, which ultimately helps keep trading costs down for investors. Additionally, it can give investors more access to global markets.

user_query: How to contribute to Roth IRA when income is at the maximum limit & you have employer-sponsored 401k plans?
text-davinci-003_response:
First, determine if you are eligible to contribute to a Roth IRA. You must meet certain income requirements, and your modified adjusted gross income (MAGI) must be less than the respective thresholds.
Once you have confirmed eligibility, you can choose to contribute either directly to a Roth IRA, or to an employer-sponsored 401k plan first, and then convert the funds to a Roth IRA.
If you choose to contribute to your 401k first, you will need to complete the required forms to roll over the funds to a Roth IRA. This is known as a “backdoor Roth IRA.” It’s important to note that if your employer’s 401k plan does not allow for Roth 401k contributions, you may not be able to use this strategy.
When contributing directly to a Roth IRA, you’ll need to pay close attention to the annual contribution limits. For the 2021 tax year, the contribution limit is $6,000, or $7,000 if you are over age 50.
Before contributing, you should consult with an accountant or tax advisor to confirm the best strategy for your situation.

user_query: What is the difference between shares and ETF?
text-davinci-003_response: Shares represents ownership of a single company. An ETF is a basket of investments that tracks an index (like the S&P 500) or a commodity (like gold). ETFs provide diversification and is a cost-efficient way to own a portfolio of assets.

user_query: Do I need to own all the funds my target-date funds owns to mimic it?
text-davinci-003_response: No, it is not necessary to own all of the funds that your target-date fund owns in order to replicate its performance. Depending on your investment strategy and risk tolerance, you may choose to invest in fewer funds or a different portfolio of funds in order to achieve similar results.

user_query: Why would I want a diversified portfolio, versus throwing my investments into an index fund?
text-davinci-003_response: When a portfolio is diversified, it is spread across various asset classes and investments. This helps to lower the risk of loss from any individual investment while also providing the potential to capture gains made in different markets. An index fund may offer diversity, but it only provides exposure to the broad market, which limits its potential to benefit during periods of market growth and takes away the opportunity to invest in emerging trends and asset classes. A diversified portfolio provides more control over investment choices, which helps an investor tailor a portfolio to meet individual needs and goals.

user_query: How can I profit on the Chinese Real-Estate Bubble?

user_query: Lump sum annuity distribution — do I owe estate tax?
text-davinci-003_response: No, a lump sum annuity distribution, which is an immediate payout of a deferred annuity, does not owe estate tax. Estate tax is only applicable to assets transferred at death, not to income received during life.
